author: pace
title: Progress and KPI reporting tool
description: The current auditing process is not community owned and managed, full reporting data is not easily available

f6_assessments.q0:
Very good idea and well written proposal. Problem statement is clear and proposal solves it accordigly.
A dedicated session expose impact is also very welcomed as it makes the value proposition clear. This proposal is a continuation from one funded in F6 and, as I understood, it actually broadens its scope in such a way that really makes sense and makes it more robust, contemplating the whole auditability process.
Other thing that will bring value to this proposal is the process of creating and implementing little by little with feedback from the community. This may help to avoid a over beurocracy on what would be a key challenge here.
As suggestions,  It would be nice to have these report metric as visual as possibles, with graphs and dashboards and possibly add a Kambam layout, so people can see the size of the backlog and what stage the tasks are in. I would also a directory to attach "proofs"/evidences of the achievements as documents.
It would be also to see a more detailed communication on plan after month 3, when iteration with more member and final roll out will happen.
f6_assessments.q1:
Pace team has already experience with this type of proposal in this campaing so chances are good the project will be a success.  As this proposal is a continuation from one funded in F6, I'd say its feasibility is high.
Plan is very clear, sensible and defined, with a road map and good milestones within.
Budget breakdown is also sensible, brokendown into project activities and hours required.
f6_assessments.q2:
the metrics are clear but could have some time-related targets. This, however, can be defined later. There are also some clear final deliverables that can be used to audit the project.


Its also possible to extract some good milestones from the roadmap/plan which helps to track project progress.

No risk is considered here. In this sense, I'd add the risk of making the process of reporting a bit more beurocratic. This can be easily overcome by the iterative implementation proposed here.

f6_assessments.q0: In the effort to attain complete self-governance for Catalyst, the community will need self-owned, public-facing progress updates for funded proposals, and the proposal teams will need efficient reporting models to build out those updates.  This proposal, building on previously funded work, seeks to accomplish both.  Their analysis of the current reporting process has already turned up a lot of low value reporting parameters that lend little to the communities understanding of project progress, and unnecessarily burden the project team  (once a project is reported as "started" why report that with every project update?).  They have also proposed numerous alternatives to these "low-value" inputs (project status updates, similar to the ideascale proposal model; clarifying the concepts of "successes/blocks" to better cover the spectrum wherein project "progress" lies; etc.).  This process has also turned up questions that need to be kicked back to the community (for example, can the process be made clearer and more accurate by auditing projects, vs auditing proposals?  Should this be factored into the toolset?), and as such, this proposal also represents Catalyst functioning as intended:  information and community input guiding projects to beneficial endgoals, even if that means changing design intent.  As another incremental step in decentralized ownership of Catalyst, this research and eventual tool implementation could have a tremendous role.
f6_assessments.q1: This highly qualified team indicates an important understanding:  self-auditing governance will be an iterative process.  To that end this proposal doesn't promise the world, rather it outlines what the end goal could achieve, and then breaks down the first careful steps in that direction.  Having said that, the roadmap and timeline lay out a steady course with simple milestones and objectives:  rollup existing tools, research and analysis into a pilot to be run on a trusted cohort within the community (they include evidence that some of these steps are already in progress), reiterate the implementation of the tool.  One of the biggest accomplishments this proposal could achieve would be an objective, easy to use KPI reporting implementation for projects, and discovery of those parameters could actually function as a KPI for this proposal.  The budget is straightforward, but has a particular line item (Initial implementation development / integrations - 120 hours) that would benefit from being less generalized, as it is half the budget.  A more granular breakdown of this item would serve both the assessment of the budget, but also the feasibility of the timeline:  what specific objectives are occurring during this major portion of the project?
f6_assessments.q2: The already available Gitbook on this project indicates that following along will be no problem for the community, and the need to collaborate with the community and the proposers indicates that transparency won't be an issue. The teams connections to Catalyst Circle, as well as other proposals in Fund7 mean they will be accessible, and likely to be a regular feature of Town Hall and Swarms. There could be more clarity in the proposal that the goal is not to roll the public database and tool out, but to iterate it until it is right (maybe that is 3 months, maybe that is 6 or more; it has a lot to do with the feedback from funded proposals, this project has a long tail).  As well, there could be more clarity in the timeline of a public database that could itself spawn other auditing tools with other parameters or reporting ability.  This database could almost be considered a deliverable of this proposal, and tracking its development would be helpful.

f6_assessments.q0: Proposal identifies the problem that the current auditing process is not community owned. Proposal will add value to the Cardano ecosystem by making funded proposals more transparent to the community, enabling the community to provide help and feedback, should the funded proposal experience trouble. The goals of getting more people to view the reports is in line with the challenge settings goals of growing auditability. The proposal is able to scale as it is open source and anyone can access the data.
f6_assessments.q1: The team has the relevant skills and are active members of the Catalyst community. The budget has been broken down into identifiable items and the time it takes to complete them with a fixed rate per hour. Taking into account how long each fund lasts, the timetable provided to complete this is reasonable. They explain how they will decide and explore different tools and ways to implement in the recording and sharing of the data. Since this is all open source and they welcome community feedback any challenges or risks will be a community effort to solve.
f6_assessments.q2: They provided roadmap with milestones at 3, 6 and 12 months. Each explaining what actions they will take and how they will use collected data. Their KPIs are number of proposers using the reporting tool and number of users viewing the data. One more interesting KPI you can ad is community contributors. The problem of making the auditing process community owned is solved by creating tools and data for the community to use and view. Also allowing the community to contribute to building this.

f6_assessments.q1:
The feasibility here is not a point that I might question since it's a fund6 funded and the project is already going. The proposal is well written and the objectives are defined.

The roadmap and the budget seem fair. 

One point that I've not noticed is the risk management here. If you don't get funded it seems that everything will stop (since everything is based in $/hours – which is correct, however it would be richer if included something)
f6_assessments.q2: All the metrics, roadmap and budget are clear stated, facilitating the tracking of this proposal. Furthermore, everything is opensource which adds value to its auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: The idea of creating a KPI reporting tool is great, and the assumption that the current audit is not managed by the community is correct. I believe that such a tool can boost audibility. A very detailed proposal with already some working parts, previous analysis and development steps. Very well-designed proposal. Rating given 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposers are divided into three groups – PACE team (Funded in F6), Catalyst Auditing circle and Community contributors. Yet, no links are provided nor a number of members of teams which would provide a more detailed idea and clarity assessing the feasibility. Feasibility is improved by open-source code, data, and meetings, and a roadmap for 3/612 months is provided in reasonable detail. 
 Rating given 5.
f6_assessments.q2:
The problem – solution is clearly stated, and the impact can be measured. The provided success metrics are focused mainly on the number of proposers, which is considered sufficient.

The audit is well described, regarding open source code, data, meetings, and cooperation with the audit catalyst circle. 

Rating given 5.

f6_assessments.q0: I definitely think this proposal can accomplish the stated goals. Create a reporting tool for progress reporting and KPIs that can be used as an alternative reporting process with completely open access data. Specific problems and solutions tailored to the challenges. The challenge proposition is pretty good.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposal involves an approved project. Now they want more money to continue their project. There are links to Links to the Web site to easily check out the project
It would be better to have several active social link profiles of at least one member of the project's team. This will give us confidence that the project will be successfully carried out by reliable and competent people. In addition, there are no reflections on possible challenges and risks.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal is relatively clear in terms of the concepts it wants to deliver, it lacks some key details that allow for measuring progress and success. A more detailed plan of the roadmap this proposal provides that can be measured would help ensure that appropriate progress is being made.
The budget given is reasonable, allocating straight to the point. The provided KPIs are easy to measure and audit.

solution: Create a reporting tool for progress and KPI reports that can be used as an alternative reporting process with full open access data
experience: Fund 6 funded community members working on auditing proposals including developers, coordinators, managers and auditors
